While running my PDE JUnit with the following parameters for profiling purposes:

-Xrunhprof:heap=sites,cpu=samples,depth=20

Under jdk1.5.0_05, Eclipse 3.1.2 and Mylar 0.5.1

I get the following:

Exception in thread "Timer-0" java.lang.NullPointerException
	at org.eclipse.mylar.provisional.tasklist.MylarTaskListPlugin.getMylarCorePrefs(MylarTaskListPlugin.java:489)
	at org.eclipse.mylar.internal.tasklist.TaskListBackupManager$CheckBackupRequired.run(TaskListBackupManager.java:155)
	at java.util.TimerThread.mainLoop(Timer.java:512)
	at java.util.TimerThread.run(Timer.java:462)
Dumping allocation sites ...HPROF ERROR: Cannot check is method native (JVMTI Error JVMTI_ERROR_INVALID_METHODID(23)) [../../../src/share/demo/jvmti/hprof/hprof_util.c:1157]
HPROF TERMINATED PROCESS

May be related to java.lang.OutOfMemory errors I get during the test suite run (we usually run with jdk1.4.2).

eclipse.buildId=M20060118-1600
java.version=1.5.0_06
java.vendor=Sun Microsystems Inc.
BootLoader constants: OS=win32, ARCH=x86, WS=win32, NL=en_US
Command-line arguments:  -os win32 -ws win32 -arch x86

The problem is that the org.eclipse.mylar.core plug-in is not loaded at the time the call is made.  It's not likely to be related to out of memory errors, but to a timer still running when the plug-ins have been deactivated, or due to a misconfiguration in the runtime workspace that's preventing the mylar.core plug-in from loading.

I've made that backup timer to ensure it it only runs when mylar.core is available, and the fix will be in Friday's dev build.
